Damage caused by native tephritid fruit flies has always been high in sub-Saharan Africa
19 . However, the arrival of the invasive pest B. dorsalis, seriously aggravated the problem, with up to a 100% damage on certain fruit crops in selected areas
34 . Management tools tailored to local parameters need to be developed and evaluated
35 . This study evaluated several parameters that are relevant for African farming settings, that impact the effectiveness of male lures in suppressing fruit fly populations and securing fruit production. These include the scale of production, potential for competitive release, field longevity of the male lure, suitability of host fruits, and the dispersive ability of the pest.
